title: Hindu Senses of Self: Critiques of Buddhist Reductionism
abstractText: Abstracts are not currently available in GtR for all funded research. This is normally because the abstract was not required at the time of proposal submission, but may be because it included sensitive information such as personal details.
findingsText: The team discovered a wide range of materials in classical and medieval Indian philosophical texts that have a bearing on contemporary discussions in philosophy and theology, which are currently dominated by the textual traditions of the West. In particular, we found that ideas about the nature of ‘self’ could play a major role in widening contemporary debates in phenomenology and analytic philosophy, as well as comparative theology Already, a younger generation of scholars working in Indian and comparative philosophy, e.g., on The Indian Philosophy Blog, have familiarized themselves with the work of the PI and the CI, and are building their own projects, in which they use the rich resources of Sanskrit and Pali texts to develop philosophical ideas about self, consciousness, ethics, God, that can contribute to proper comparative study with Western philosophy. Also, members of the Hindu community, as well as others, continue to apply for research study with tthe PI and the CI Culture, Heritage, Museums and Collections
